Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot. The relative lengths of the arrows should reflect the relative magnitudes of the forces.

(b) At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the mass of the lander and its fuel is <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Write your answers for parts (b)(i) and (b)(ii) in terms of <math alttext="uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, <math alttext="uppercase M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="v sub e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="g sub lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.i. Derive an equation for the rate <math alttext="derivative of uppercase M, with respect to t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi><mi>M</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></math> at which the hovering lander expels exhaust fuel as a function of <math alttext="uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. Using your derivation from part (b)(i), derive an equation for the mass of the lander and its remaining fuel as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

At time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, there is no remaining fuel in the lander.(c) On the following axes, sketch a graph of <math alttext="F sub thrust" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>thrust</mi></msub></math> as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

(d) Consider the case of a hovering lander with an engine that expels its exhaust gases at a speed greater than <math alttext="v sub e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></msub></math>, but the mass of the lander and the initial mass of fuel do not change.i. Describe how one feature of one of the graphs drawn in part (c) would change.
ii. Briefly justify your answer using either qualitative reasoning or by referencing the equation derived in part (b).
